Authors: Mariana Del Olmo Ruiz, A. Elizabeth Arnold
Title:
Community structure of fern-affiliated endophytes in three
neotropical forests
Keywords:
Endophytic fungi, eupolypod ferns, community structure,
fungal diversity, tropical forests
Abstract:
Although abundant and diverse in many biomes, endophytic
fungi are thought to reach their greatest diversity in tropical forests.
However, turnover in endophyte communities among different tropical
forests has not been evaluated rigorously, limiting inferences regarding
(1) the scale of tropical endophyte diversity and (2) the contributions
of endophytes to global estimates of fungal species richness. In this
culture-based study we compared the endophytic fungal communities
associated with closely related eupolypod ferns in three forest reserves
in Panama, Costa Rica, and Mexico. Using molecular sequence data for
>2000 isolates we evaluated the relative contributions of host
taxonomy, forest (site), and environmental dissimilarity to endophyte
community composition. Our study reveals high turnover in endophyte
communities among fern species within sites, and among related ferns in
three neotropical forests. These differences are correlated with
geographic distance and environmental dissimilarity among sites.
Phylogenetic reconstructions of endophyte relationships reveal the
evolutionary context of ecological analyses based on operational
taxonomic units (OTU), and corroborate our findings of high beta
diversity at the OTU level. Together, these findings indicate that
extrapolative estimates of fungal diversity should take host, locality,
and environmental variation among sites into account, and that tropical
endophytes at a large scale may be more diverse than previously
thought.
